Roots: TREE Lab Learning Platform

  • Overview

    The goal of this particular project was to develop a learning platform for the Technology, Race, Ethics, and Equity (TREE) Lab and create its first learning module to discuss facial recognition technologies and their social implications.

    My role in this project was as a software engineer and technical program manager through the development of interactive demos and front-end interfaces as well as the management of my team of 4 student researchers.

  • Role

    Software Engineer
    UI/UX Designer
    Technical Program Manager

  • Timeline

    10 WEEKS

  • Tools

    HTML
    CSS/SASS
    JavaScript
    Python
    Flask

  • Outcome

Joining any startup is never a step that is taken lightly, especially when it requires weekends and working out of hours to bootstrap things together, and demonstrates genuine leadership. The most essential element of leadership is having a vision for how to make a difference, to make a change for the better or decide where to go. Titobi should be commended for her passion and drive to try and make an improvement in the world, in an area that so desperately needs it.

-Funmilola Williams, Mother

Background

With the growth of Google's Grasshopper, Khan Academy, and Coursera; it has become more apparent that the democratisation of technical skills is providing individuals of diverse backgrounds access to solely technical knowledge. Roots and its first learning module in Facial Recognition are designed to fill the void of bridging technical and ethical education by deconstructing technical concepts and engaging in critical discussion of the potential uses of the product and who is affected positively and adversely.

I was the sole designer of the founding team.

I led the development of Roots and its Facial Recognition module as part of a team of 4 students. I oversaw development of software to be used in the interactive demos, created an overall strategy for the product, and tracked their progress throughout the project. Additionally, I implemented interactive demos and designed the Roots platform.

I've grown tremendously in the course of this project, some key achievements of which I have listed below:

  • Turned an idea into a product. I worked closely with my team and research lab to shape the product vision and strategy of its learning platform. In doing so, I have improved my management skills through practicing prioritization, communication, and building a clear process for team members and myself to implement changes.

  • Juggled many different roles. Working in the early-stages of this product was exciting as I dedicated hours of my spare time and weekends conducting user research, sketching mockups, testing software and designing the interactive demos alongside coordinating team members and writing code.

  • Conducted the design process. Through this project I designed and implemented the front-end for this project. My process was gathering user research, following design principles, and user testing.

Defining the Problem Statement

Motivation

We wanted to use the Facial Recognition learning module as an opportunity to explain technical processes that people experience every day but may not be aware of its innerworkings. After reading about the ethical, legal, and social ramifications of these technologies, we found that sources of critical analysis did not emphasize the technical and technical resources did not stress ethics.

User Personas

Based on our research, we recognised that there were 2 key user types that our product was applicable. We decided to focus on these personas since their need was greatest and we could reach them via universities and educational programs.

Whitespace Research

What kind of projects, research, and products already existed in this realm and what whitespaces existed that we could contribute to?

We found 3 main types of works:

❮ ❯

Ideating & Development

Brainstorming

Glancing towards existent learning platforms, objectives we needed to fulfill was a platform that prioritized the modules and made navigation within each learning module intuitive. Challenges in the development of the Facial Recognition module were defining an audience of the module and creating an approachable method to explain technical programming concepts such as machine learning, algorithms, and time complexity to people of non-technical backgrounds. To combat this, we excluded programming skills and abstracted programming concepts to teach users what these concepts do without overwheling them with technical specifics.

Taking our ideas to paper + pencil, we landed on creating a clearly outlined process for Facial Recognition:

  1. Facial Detection
  2. Facial Mapping
  3. Facial Comparison
  4. Facial Recognition

Protoyping

In order to prototype my idea, I first drew out a simple storyboard. Once my ideas were organized, we then took to PowerPoint to create a mid-fidelity mock-up.

User Testing

Although our prototype was still a ways off from the final product, we conducted testing with 5 users. We drew 3 main insights from our testing:

  1. There was no clear navigational process or indication of the next page in the course.
  2. Lack of user control - users wanted a way to easily access where there are in the course without having to scroll all the way up and backtracking.
  3. Inconsistencies with formatting - users found the interactive demo element confusing because, at times, it would be a video, picture, or gif. Our design lacked continuation from one step to the next that gives the demos a cohesive feel.

Software Development

To develop the product, I used HTML, CSS/SASS, and JavaScript to build the Roots learning platform. In order to further learners understanding of technical concepts, I built interactive demonstrations of Facial Recognition concepts like facial mapping, and facial comparison using Python and Flask.

Results & Reflection

Initiating, designing, and developing this product was an extremely rewarding experience. It re-affirmed my interest in software enginnering and exploring the intersection of technology and education. Further, challenges I faced were communication with my team, learning new technologies, and designing a meaningful UX. In the beginning of the project, everyone on my team had differing visions of who the target users were, the content of the learning module, and what tools were to be used in building the product. I resolved this by developing clear user personas to give tangible meaning to what constitutes our user base. This project ignited my interest in front-end engineering in my task to design and implement the learning platform and course module. I gained invaluable experience with Jekyll, Adobe InDesign, Figma, JavaScript, and Ruby.

Some key takeaways from this project are:

  • Clear communication is key. There is only so much work that can be completed on your own. It is important to be transparent with your team members about your progress and ideas.

  • Don't worry too much about the detail. Earlier in my journey, I made the mistake of worrying about the look of the UI. Taking a step back and reassessing the user flows helped me to reprioritize the UX.

  • Focus on the problem. In the beginning of development, I was focused too much on selecitng the best tools to create the best solution; however, reframing to focus on the problem and user personas clarified our product and next steps in the process.
